metadata.official_name: University of Notre Dame du Lac

strategic_profile.executive_summary: The University of Notre Dame is a private Catholic research university in Indiana, renowned for its strong academic programs, vibrant residential life, and deep-seated traditions. It is recognized for fostering intellectual growth and moral character while pursuing breakthroughs in research to serve humanity.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: The University of Notre Dame practices a holistic review process for admissions. For undergraduates, it is one of only 10 schools that offers need-blind admissions and meets full demonstrated need for all students, domestic and international. For graduate programs, such as the Philosophy PhD, admission is highly selective, focusing on the quality of a philosophical paper, academic background, letters of recommendation, and GRE scores (though optional), emphasizing a good fit with the department's specializations.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Notre Dame has an undergraduate acceptance rate of 18%, indicating high selectivity. It is among the top national universities with a low acceptance rate.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students need strong academic credentials and compelling applications to gain admission.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The University boasts a 99% retention rate for first-year students and a 97% six-year graduation rate, among the highest in the country.
analyst_takeaways.implication: This indicates a highly supportive and engaging academic and social environment that contributes to student success and satisfaction.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Notre Dame is known for its strong sense of community, particularly through its unique residential life system where undergraduates often live in the same residence hall for all four years, fostering close-knit communities with distinct traditions.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students seeking a strong, enduring on-campus community experience with rich traditions will find Notre Dame a good fit. This also influences social life, which often revolves around dorm events and campus activities, in addition to athletics.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Notre Dame's social environment is deeply influenced by its unique residential life system, where undergraduates live in the same residence hall for all four years, fostering strong, close-knit communities with their own traditions and events. A significant aspect of campus life revolves around its strong athletic traditions, particularly Fighting Irish football games, which are a major highlight. As a Catholic institution, faith and spirituality also play a special role, with various related activities and an atmosphere of open dialogue and inclusivity for all backgrounds. Students are academically rigorous but maintain a work-life balance through over 500 clubs and organizations. While some social life may involve alcohol, the university also provides events and support for non-drinkers, and a strong sense of 'Notre Dame family' is often cited by students.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: The University of Notre Dame is located in Notre Dame, Indiana, adjacent to South Bend, offering a mix of small-town charm and access to urban amenities. The closest airport is South Bend International Airport (SBN), about 15-20 minutes from campus. For those flying into Chicago O'Hare (ORD), transportation options to South Bend are limited, but students can take a train (South Shore Line or Amtrak) from Chicago to South Bend and then a taxi to campus, or utilize limited shuttle services offered by the university in August for new students. On campus, Notre Dame operates three convenient shuttle routes that run continuously Monday through Friday, with real-time tracking available via the ND Mobile app. Transpo, South Bend's bus company, offers free service for students, with routes connecting campus to areas like University Park Mall and Downtown South Bend, and also provides service between Notre Dame, Holy Cross College, and Saint Mary's College. Zipcar is also available for students aged 18 and older, encouraging students to leave their personal cars at home. Overall, while regional public transportation can be limited from larger cities like Chicago, on-campus and local off-campus transportation is well-supported.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Notre Dame is classified among 'R1: Doctoral Universities – Very high research spending and doctorate production' and is the only explicitly religious institution in the Association of American Universities (AAU). Research at Notre Dame is driven by a mission to serve humanity, focusing on discovery not as an end in itself, but as a means to make a real-world impact. Key areas of focus include sustainability, health (e.g., cancer therapies, allergy treatment), and ethical implications of artificial intelligence. Researchers work across disciplines, both on campus and globally, with efforts extending into practical applications like clean water systems and combating addiction. The university provides significant resources and infrastructure through Notre Dame Research to support faculty and student innovation, with over one-third of undergraduates participating in original research with faculty mentors. This commitment aims to advance human understanding and make a positive difference in the world.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Record-breaking number of applications. Acceptance rates: REA 12.9%, RD 6.7%. University expanded need-blind admissions to international students. More detailed enrollment information will be available in late August 2025. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed yet for this class.
Highest yield rate since the creation of the Common App. Acceptance rate was 11.1% (preliminary), down from 11.9% a year ago. Waitlist data is from the Common Data Set 2024-2025.

Lowest acceptance rate in Notre Dame history at the time. A limited number of students were offered a place on the waiting list. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed for this class beyond being unranked.
Applications increased significantly over the previous year. REA admitted students historically enroll at close to a 70% rate. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed, but it is unranked based on CDS.
Applications surged during the pandemic years, influenced by test-optional policies. Waitlist data is from the Common Data Set 2020-2021.

gpa.notes: The average GPA is 4.13, suggesting successful applicants typically have nearly straight A's in all their classes, including challenging AP or IB courses.

testing.policy_note: Test optional, scores are considered if submitted.

men.note: Approximately 50.41% of full-time undergraduates are men.

women.note: Approximately 49.59% of full-time undergraduates are women.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Letters
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a broad liberal arts education with flexible major options across humanities, social sciences, and arts.
colleges.housing_profile: Part of the strong residential college system where dorms foster community, traditions, and rivalries. Students typically remain in the same dorm for all four years. Newer dorms may have AC, while older ones emphasize community. Undergraduates are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, values a well-rounded education, potentially interested in interdisciplinary studies.

majors.name: Political Science
weeder_courses: POLS 10000-level introductory courses in American Politics, International Relations, World Politics, Political Theory
majors.notes: Requires 11 courses (31 credit hours) for the graduating class of 2028 and beyond. Introductory courses in the four main fields are required.

majors.name: Economics
weeder_courses: MATH 10350 Calculus A or MATH 10550 Calculus I
majors.notes: One of the most popular majors at Notre Dame.

majors.name: English
majors.notes: Requires a minimum of 10 courses (30 credit hours). Many students double major due to flexibility.

majors.name: Psychology
majors.notes: Requires a minimum of 30 credit hours of psychology courses. Introductory Psychology is a prerequisite for 300-level courses.

majors.name: History
majors.notes: Requires 10 three-credit history courses. Honors track suggests a cumulative GPA of 3.8 in the major.

majors.name: Philosophy
majors.notes: Major begins with three core classes: Ancient & Medieval Philosophy, Modern Philosophy, and Formal Logic. Honors track requires a 3.5 GPA in major courses.

majors.name: Computer Science (Arts & Letters)
majors.notes: A Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science is offered by the College of Arts & Letters, distinct from the College of Engineering's B.S. in Computer Science.

colleges.name: College of Science
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong STEM background and an interest in scientific research or pre-professional health tracks. Notre Dame's science pre-professional program has one of the highest acceptance rates to medical school.
colleges.housing_profile: Part of the strong residential college system where dorms foster community, traditions, and rivalries. Some female dorms are designated as 'STEM dorms' for first-year students to provide a supportive environment. Students typically remain in the same dorm for all four years. Undergraduates are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Analytical thinkers, dedicated to rigorous scientific study, high achieving, potentially pre-med or pre-health focused. Stereotypically experiences stress from demanding courses like organic chemistry.

majors.name: Biological Sciences
weeder_courses: CHEM 10171/11171 Introduction to Chemical Principles (with lab)
majors.notes: Strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry is essential.

majors.name: Chemistry
weeder_courses: CHEM 10181/11181 Intro to Chemical Principles (with lab)
CHEM 10182/11182 Organic Structure and Mechanism (with lab)
majors.notes: Curriculum designed for professional careers in chemistry or combination with other fields. Honors program requires a minimum GPA of 3.5.

majors.name: Physics
majors.notes: Requires a strong foundation in mathematics and physics.

majors.name: Applied and Computational Mathematics and Statistics (ACMS)
weeder_courses: ACMS 20550 Introduction to Applied Mathematics Methods I
ACMS 20750 Introduction to Applied Mathematical Methods II
majors.notes: Focuses on applied mathematics and data analysis with computational skills.

majors.name: Neuroscience
weeder_courses: CHEM 10171/11171 Introduction to Chemical Principles (with lab)
majors.notes: Interdisciplinary major drawing from biological sciences, psychology, and chemistry.

colleges.name: Notre Dame Law School
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Aspirants to legal careers, particularly those interested in a program with a strong Catholic intellectual tradition. It is the oldest law program at a Catholic university in the U.S.
colleges.housing_profile: Graduate and professional students typically have different housing options or may live off-campus. Undergraduate students are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Motivated, analytical, strong academic record, and a clear interest in legal studies.

colleges.name: School of Architecture
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for students passionate about architectural design, history, and urbanism within a rigorous academic framework.
colleges.housing_profile: Part of the strong residential college system where dorms foster community, traditions, and rivalries. Students typically remain in the same dorm for all four years. Undergraduates are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Creative, detail-oriented, diligent, and interested in both the artistic and technical aspects of building and design.

majors.name: Architecture
majors.special_requirements: Portfolio submission required for transfer applicants. Must be entering for the first semester of sophomore year for transfer.
majors.notes: Five-year undergraduate program. Third year is spent studying in Rome. Transfer applicants must have completed specific first-year coursework and submit a portfolio. Generally does not accept transfers after the first semester of sophomore year.

colleges.name: College of Engineering
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: For students with a strong aptitude for mathematics and science, aiming to solve complex problems through engineering principles.
colleges.housing_profile: Part of the strong residential college system where dorms foster community, traditions, and rivalries. Students typically remain in the same dorm for all four years. Undergraduates are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers, logical, resilient, and focused on practical applications of scientific knowledge.

majors.name: Aerospace Engineering
majors.notes: Curriculum based on mathematics, physics, chemistry, and engineering sciences. Major is declared at the beginning of sophomore year.

majors.name: Chemical Engineering
weeder_courses: CHEM 10171/11171 Introduction to Chemical Principles (with lab)
majors.notes: Foundational coursework in mathematics, physics, and chemistry is common to all engineering students.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.notes: Students declare their major at the beginning of the sophomore year.

majors.name: Computer Engineering
weeder_courses: CSE 20133 Introduction to Computing for EE Majors
majors.notes: Focuses on the intersection of hardware and software. Common foundational courses with other engineering majors in the first year.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
weeder_courses: CSE 20133 Introduction to Computing for EE Majors
majors.notes: First year of study includes foundational math, science, and introduction to engineering. Major declaration at the beginning of sophomore year.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.notes: Curriculum built on a foundation of mathematics, physics, chemistry, and engineering sciences. Major is declared at the beginning of sophomore year.

colleges.name: Mendoza College of Business
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: A good fit for students aiming for careers in business, finance, accounting, or marketing, who also value networking and a vibrant social scene.
colleges.housing_profile: Part of the strong residential college system where dorms foster community, traditions, and rivalries. Students typically remain in the same dorm for all four years. Undergraduates are required to live on-campus for their first six semesters.
colleges.student_archetype: Career-focused, confident, social, and often perceived as adept at balancing academics with social 'networking.' Some stereotypes suggest a culture of privilege and perceived entitlement.

majors.name: Accountancy
majors.notes: Enrollment is capped. Students declare their business major in the spring semester of their first year. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the major is required to graduate. The 3+1 accelerated degree option to the MSA program requires a 3.0 GPA after three years.

majors.name: Finance
majors.notes: Enrollment is capped. Students declare their business major in the spring semester of their first year. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the major is required to graduate.

majors.name: Marketing
majors.notes: Enrollment is capped. Students declare their business major in the spring semester of their first year. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the major is required to graduate.

majors.name: Business Analytics
majors.notes: Enrollment is capped. Students declare their business major in the spring semester of their first year. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the major is required to graduate. The curriculum includes data management, data mining, predictive analytics, machine learning, and visualization.

majors.name: Strategic Management
majors.notes: Renamed from Management Consulting for the Class of 2026. Enrollment is capped. Students declare their business major in the spring semester of their first year. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the major is required to graduate.

colleges.name: Keough School of Global Affairs
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for those committed to addressing global challenges, fostering integral human development, and engaging in international research and policy.
colleges.housing_profile: Primarily caters to graduate students who may have different housing options or live off-campus.
colleges.student_archetype: Globally-minded, socially conscious, policy-driven, and interested in peace, justice, and international development.

minors_certificates: Middle Eastern and North African Studies (MENA) Minor

application_deadlines.notes: Non-binding, but restricts applying to other private colleges' Early Decision 1 or Early Action programs. Supporting application documents due November 15, 2025.

supplemental_requirements.details: One required essay (150 words) on 'non-negotiable factors when searching for your future college home' and three short-answer responses (50-100 words each) chosen from five options, including 'How do you foster service to others in your community?'.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Looking for intellectual curiosity and drive, commitment to Notre Dame's Catholic mission, compelling service to others, and a diverse portfolio of lived experiences.

essay_prompts.prompt: Everyone has different priorities when considering their higher education options. Tell us about your 'non-negotiable' factor(s) when searching for your future college home.
brainstorming_questions: When you picture yourself thriving at Notre Dame, what's one specific experience or aspect of campus life that you absolutely can't imagine not being a part of, and why is that particular element so essential to your vision of a fulfilling college journey?

Beyond academics and general prestige, what unique opportunity or tradition at Notre Dame resonates so deeply with your personal values that you would consider it a deal-breaker if it weren't present?

Think about moments where you've felt truly challenged and supported. What kind of community or specific resource at Notre Dame do you believe would be indispensable for you to continue growing in that way?

If you had to distill your ideal college environment down to its absolute core, what essential element of Notre Dame's ethos or mission would you say is your ultimate 'must-have' for your educational and personal development?

When you envision your future self contributing to the Notre Dame community, what specific kind of impact or engagement feels non-negotiable for you, and how does Notre Dame uniquely enable that particular contribution?

essay_prompts.prompt: How does faith influence the decisions you make?
brainstorming_questions: Think about a time you had to make a difficult choice where the 'right' thing felt exceptionally challenging or even went against your immediate desires – what inner compass, which you might describe as faith, guided you through that dilemma, and how did you recognize that guidance?

Beyond just following rules, how has your faith provided you with a framework for understanding the world and your place in it, and can you recall a specific instance where this worldview directly shaped a decision you made, even when others might have chosen differently?

Notre Dame's motto is 'Crescit scientia, caritas et veritas.' Considering the 'caritas' (charity/love) aspect of your faith, can you describe a situation where your commitment to loving and serving others, stemming from your faith, led you to a decision that might seem unconventional or require significant personal sacrifice?

Reflect on a moment when your faith challenged your assumptions or forced you to re-evaluate something you previously believed to be true. How did this internal wrestling match with your faith lead you to a specific decision or action, and what did you learn about yourself in that process?

In what ways has your faith encouraged you to pursue knowledge and truth, as suggested by Notre Dame's pursuit of 'scientia' and 'veritas,' and can you pinpoint a decision you've made – perhaps in your academic pursuits, extracurricular activities, or personal growth – that was fundamentally driven by this faith-inspired quest?

essay_prompts.prompt: Notre Dame's undergraduate experience is characterized by a collective sense of care for every person. How do you foster service to others in your community?
brainstorming_questions: Beyond formal volunteering, can you recall a specific moment where you felt a strong, almost innate urge to help someone in your immediate community, and what made that impulse so powerful for you?

Think about a time you encountered a challenge within a group or community you were part of, and instead of just solving the problem, you prioritized making sure everyone felt heard and supported. What did that process teach you about fostering care?

Notre Dame emphasizes a 'collective sense of care.' Can you describe an experience where you witnessed this kind of widespread care for another person in your community, and how did that inspire or influence your own approach to service?

When you think about 'service to others,' what's a specific, perhaps unexpected, way you've contributed that went beyond typical expectations and demonstrated a deeper level of care for those around you?

Imagine a new student arriving at Notre Dame and feeling a bit lost or disconnected. Based on your experiences, what tangible actions would you take to ensure they felt that Notre Dame sense of care, and why are those actions important to you?
Thinking about Notre Dame's mission of service and leadership, when have you felt a powerful, almost visceral urge to stand up for someone or something, even when it was difficult or unpopular?

Beyond the obvious causes, what are the smaller, perhaps even everyday, injustices or imbalances you've observed that have struck a chord with you and made you want to advocate for change, even on a personal level?

Consider a time when you witnessed or experienced something that challenged your understanding of fairness or the 'right way' things should be, and how did that experience shape what you feel compelled to defend?

Given Notre Dame's Catholic identity and emphasis on human dignity, what core values or beliefs have you found yourself defending most fiercely, perhaps in discussions with others or in your own internal convictions?

Imagine yourself as a future leader inspired by the Notre Dame spirit – what is a specific, tangible improvement or a deeper sense of justice in a community you've been part of that you would dedicate yourself to achieving, even against significant obstacles?

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive major if not set on CS/Engineering
Consider undeclared for Letters and Science to explore options, as some UCs admit undeclared students into those colleges
Research major-specific admit rates and program competitiveness before applying
Take introductory classes in a variety of subjects during college to discover genuine interests
Choose a major that offers transferable skills and has a good job outlook
college_ranking_tactics: Rank colleges based on general education (GE) requirements and program-specific strengths, not solely on overall prestige
Consider student-reported housing quality when evaluating colleges
Evaluate student outcomes such as graduation rates and retention rates
Look at the institution's affordability and the potential return on investment (ROI) for specific majors
Examine faculty resources, including class sizes and student-faculty ratios
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a highly competitive major, list a backup in a different college within the same university. For example, if applying to Computer Science in the College of Engineering, list Cognitive Science in the College of Letters and Science as an alternate, ensuring the alternate major aligns with genuine interest.

scholarships.name: Notre Dame Scholars' Program
scholarships.amount: Full tuition or $25,000 per year (totaling $100,000 over four years)
scholarships.benefits: Financial support, potential additional funding for special projects (service, leadership, academics)

scholarships.name: Stamps Scholarship at Notre Dame
scholarships.amount: Full tuition and fees, plus estimated cost of books, personal expenses, and transportation
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration; interview required for semi-finalists
scholarships.benefits: Covers tuition, fees, books, personal expenses, transportation; enrichment funds for academic and professional development
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration; Interview required for semi-finalists

scholarships.name: QuestBridge Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Four-year, full-ride scholarship (covers tuition, housing, food, books, supplies, travel, personal expenses, fees)
scholarships.benefits: Comprehensive coverage of attendance costs, including health insurance if needed

scholarships.name: Notre Dame Need-Based Grants/Scholarships
scholarships.amount: Varies; meets 100% of demonstrated financial need
scholarships.benefits: Covers demonstrated financial need through grants and federal loans

scholarships.name: Notre Dame Club Scholarships
scholarships.amount: Varies based on demonstrated financial need
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with financial aid application; local clubs may have additional steps
scholarships.benefits: Financial assistance from local Notre Dame alumni clubs
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration with Financial Aid Application

scholarships.name: Graduate Tuition Scholarship (Doctoral Programs)
scholarships.deadline: Varies by graduate program admission deadline
scholarships.benefits: Full tuition coverage, often combined with stipends for living expenses
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration with Graduate Admission Application

ap_policy.general_rule: Accepts AP scores for credit, but credit generally does not satisfy University, college, major, or minor requirements.
exceptions: A score of 4 or 5 on AP English Language and Composition grants credit for Writing and Rhetoric, but requires a Writing Intensive course instead.
Life science and pre-health majors cannot use AP credit for biology, chemistry, or physics courses.
AP credits may count for General Elective credit and for programs where expressly permitted by departments.
ap_policy.usage: Can count towards total credit hours needed for graduation; limited application to specific requirements, often leads to placement or requires alternative coursework.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with scores of 6 or 7 grant credit, depending on the exam; no credit for Standard Level (SL) exams.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Transfer credits must be from accredited institutions with a grade of 'C' or better; pre-approval often required; asynchronous online courses generally not accepted, synchronous reviewed case-by-case; a minimum of 60 credits must be earned at Notre Dame for a degree; dual enrollment courses generally not accepted for advanced standing for incoming freshmen.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with rigorous coursework (AP, IB, Honors classes) and high GPA (aim for 4.0+).
Demonstrated unique 'spike' or exceptional talent and dedication in 1-2 specific areas, showing quality over quantity in extracurriculars.
Capacity for empathy, humility, growth, intellectual curiosity, and a sense of purpose to be a 'force for good'.
Competitive standardized test scores (if submitted), with successful applicants often having SAT scores between 1440-1540 or ACT scores of 33-35.
Strong recommendations from teachers and counselors.
common_activities: Leadership roles in school clubs and organizations.
Community service and commitment to service, often highlighted due to Notre Dame's Catholic mission.
Research experience, especially if tied to specific Notre Dame programs or faculty.
Involvement in arts (e.g., marching band) or unique hobbies.
essay_tips: Be authentic, introspective, and let your personality shine through; essays serve as a written interview since Notre Dame does not offer interviews.
Show, don't tell, and use specific details about why Notre Dame is the right fit for you, mentioning specific programs, traditions, or values.
Focus on how a personal experience, tradition, or passion has impacted you and how you plan to contribute to the Notre Dame community.
Avoid generic essays that could apply to any school and refrain from talking about specific colleges other than Notre Dame in your common application essay.
Take risks and choose a topic that truly expresses who you are, rather than what you think admissions officers want to hear.
red_flags: Generic essays that lack personal voice or could apply anywhere.
Lack of demonstrated interest or understanding of Notre Dame's mission and values.
Focusing solely on a long list of extracurriculars without demonstrating deep involvement or leadership.
Poorly written essays with errors or incomprehensible language.
Assuming legacy status guarantees admission; a non-competitive student will still be non-competitive.
insights: Notre Dame employs a holistic admissions approach, considering the entire applicant.
Applying Restrictive Early Action (REA) can boost admissions odds, as Notre Dame takes a significant portion of its class from this pool (around 60%).
While a Catholic university with a large Catholic student body (around 80%), Notre Dame welcomes students from all religious backgrounds.
The strong sense of community and school spirit, particularly around athletics, are defining aspects of the student experience.
There is no Greek life; the single-sex dorms foster a strong sense of community that replaces fraternities and sororities.
